english: refined; cultured; combining civil and martial virtues; elegant

etymology.description: semantic: 文 (“civil; culture”) + 武 (“martial; military”).
etymology.interpretation: Combines 文 ‘civil refinement’ with 武 ‘martial prowess’, conveying a harmony of cultured grace and strength. From this fusion arose senses like refined, elegant, and possessing both civil and martial virtues.

examples.chinese: 斌先生很有修养(斌先生很有修養)。
父母给他取名“斌”，希望他文武兼备(父母給他取名「斌」，希望他文武兼備)。
examples.pinyin: Fùmǔ gěi tā qǔmíng “Bīn”, xīwàng tā wénwǔ jiānbèi.
examples.english: His parents named him “Bin,” hoping he would be both cultured and martial.

examples.chinese: 小斌勤学书法也练武(小斌勤學書法也練武)，气质沉稳而优雅(氣質沉穩而優雅)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎo Bīn qínxué shūfǎ yě liànwǔ, qìzhì chénwěn ér yōuyǎ.
examples.english: Young Bin studies calligraphy and also practices martial arts; his demeanor is steady and elegant.
